awd_titl_txt: Polymer Semiconductor Focal Volume Arrays for Advanced Multidimensional Imaging
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical:
Consumer digital cameras form an image using inorganic materials like silicon. These materials are attractive as they are durable, efficient, and low cost. However, they only detect light in a single layer. Multi-layer structures offer significant advantages in terms of improved color reproduction, but at increased cost and reduced image resolution. In this project, we will investigate new multi-layer cameras that can offer improved color reproduction without sacrificing image resolution. The multi-layer camera concept will also be studied for capturing more than the three colors of a typical camera (red, green, and blue). This will be done by using holographic lenses and by manipulating the polarization of light as it passes through the different layers. Finally, the multi-layer detector scheme will be used to improve so called "light field" imaging, in which a single camera lens can be made to capture depth information, enabling improved "digital refocusing" capabilities. Both graduate and undergraduate student researchers will be involved in this research. The project will also facilitate outreach activities to local high school students and online tutorials will be disseminated to encourage participation from avid hobbyists and students.

Technical: 
This project will develop the first three-dimensional (3D) volumetric imaging array by leveraging the unique advantages offered by emerging organic photovoltaic detectors. These new detector-based degrees of freedom will permit an extra dimension onto which information can be modulated, enabling more compact, robust, and capable optical imaging sensors and systems. Organic semiconductors are advantageous to realize this concept due to their ability to tune spectral response, polarization sensitivity, and transmittance, enabling detector placement arbitrarily within a lens system's focal volume. These new degrees of freedom will be used to investigate new detector capabilities, optical systems, and image processing algorithms. The objectives of this proposal are to: (1) Establish an optical model of both 2D and 3D polarization sensitive organic photodetector (P-OPD) arrays; (2) Design and fabricate proof of concept 2D and 3D P-OPD arrays and readout circuitry; (3) Create algorithms for image reconstruction and calibration; (4) Leverage the model to optimize spectral- and polarimetric- imaging array using birefringent filtering techniques; and (5) Incorporate methods to create multi-layer volumetric 3D P-OPD arrays with liquid crystal layers. Merit is found in (1) The optimization strategies and algorithms needed to design 3D volumetric arrays; (2) Use of polarized light for detector-level spectral sensitivity; (3) Establishing new calibration algorithms and image reconstruction techniques; and (4) Quantifying the multiplexing trade space that can be achieved with these 3D arrays, given conventional and emerging optical devices and lens systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project explored how controlling light polarization can enhance detection capabilities using the semi-transparency and intrinsic polarization sensitivity of organic photovoltaic detectors. We demonstrated that these detectors offer advanced sensing suitable for uses like automated cars, chemical sensing, and mobile phones. Five graduate students contributed to this research, and outreach included leading K-12 science camp activities in the initial year.

Intellectual Merit

1. Development of biaxially oriented conjugated polymer films with dichroic ratios of over 35.

Our team has refined a method to align polymer films effectively. By adjusting the process, we managed to closely align these films, achieving an alignment score close to the ideal. This involved stretching the film and then heating it to a specific point, allowing the polymer to take a certain shape. This method can help make materials that are sensitive to polarized light. We're preparing a detailed report on this process.

2. Fabrication of small area organic photodetectors for multispectral imaging

We developed devices that effectively detect multiple light colors using organic photodetectors combined with a special lens. These detectors were made to let through as much light as possible. We used a mix of specific materials to make the active layer of the device and then tailored it to minimize light loss. A special process using lasers helped finish the device. These devices responded well to a range of visible light. Additionally, we made versions of these detectors on flexible materials embedded with tiny silver wires. We further enhanced these flexible detectors to reduce unwanted electrical noise, achieving performance comparable to their non-flexible counterparts, but with a slight increase in this noise.

3. Proof-of-concept of a new CiMOS sensor

We developed a new sensor design that combines organic photodetectors with a specific lens. This lens was tailored to focus on light around the 550 nm wavelength. The detectors were positioned at specific distances from the lens, enabling them to capture light at four distinct wavelengths. We used a broad light source and a tool called a monochromator to direct various light wavelengths to the sensor. By measuring the sensor's response, we found that it effectively detected four distinct colors in the light spectrum.

4. Biaxially oriented conjugated polymer films with dichroic ratios of over 35

Through processing optimization we achieved nearly perfectly aligned conjugated polymer thin films with a 2D order parameter of over 0.97. Here, the perfect in-plane alignment would be 1 and no alignment is 0. The high degree of alignment resulted in a dichroic ratio of over 35. The alignment was achieved by straining the film followed by heating the polymer right to its liquid crystal to isotropization transition where the polymer templates off seed crystals. This result should assist in developing highly polarization-sensitive polymer semiconductors for the polarized light detectors. A manuscript on the topic is currently in preparation. 

5. Development of a tandem Mantis-shrimp inspired multi-spectral polarization detector.

We developed and tested a new sensor (SIMPOL) through a series of experiments to determine its effectiveness. To do this, we used a moving stage to scan a target, which in this case was an image of seven colored pencils that had been printed onto a special film. The goal was for each detector in our setup to produce distinct images based on either the color or polarization of the light. Our results showed that the detectors were indeed sensitive to specific colors, and the sensor was able to recreate the image of the colored pencils quite accurately. We checked the accuracy of these recreated images by comparing them to standard measurements, and the differences were minimal, only around 2.17% on average. We also looked at how the sensor measured the direction and intensity of light waves, known as polarization. These tests also yielded good results, with small errors of about 1.35% and 1.19%. The results also matched our expectations based on theoretical calculations. In summary, the experiments confirmed that the SIMPOL sensor could accurately detect different colors and measure light polarization in a compact design.

Broader Impact

6. Development and dissemination of a high school student summer camp challenge project. 

We have offered a new summer camp materials in June of 2019 to approximately 150 high school students. The materials were related to the topic of Free Space Optical Communication and included: Two different PowerPoint presentations designed for the intro and challenge activities, video tutorials, student guides for both the intro and challenge activities and different optical and electrical equipment as well as basic tools to help students assemble their own optical communication system. Overall the summer camp went very well. Students, involved in the activities, showed passion and eagerness while performing the different tasks. We have received positive comments from both the students and summer camp organizers.

7. Approximately 5 graduate students and 4 REU students were trained.
